Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Statistics-Guided Framework for Synthesis and Characterization of Nanomaterials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research goal of this collaborative research award is to develop a statistics-guided framework for significantly enhancing the efficiency of nano-synthesis and the accuracy of nano-characterization in nanomanufacturing. The research seeks to produce transformative computational and analytic methods for advancing the reproducibility, reliability, efficiency and precision of nanomaterials. These new methods include a level-expansion experimental design for sequential synthesis of nanomaterials, a sequential tapering method for accurate characterization of nanomaterial surface potential with massive data and a functional data analysis approach for identifying phase truncation in nano-characterization. These methods can significantly enhance both the lab-scale development of nanoparticles, nanowires and complex nanoarchitectures, and industrial scale nanomanufacturing.

If successful, the results of this research are expected to accelerate the scale-up and standardization of experiments in nanomanufacturing. These results will be disseminated broadly to the nanotechnology community. Beyond nanomanufacturing, the statistical and computational methods developed in this research will have broad applications to other fields in manufacturing and enterprise systems such as multi-stage manufacturing processes, logistics and health care. Undergraduate and graduate students will benefit from this research through rigorous training in statistics and nanotechnology. A dynamic platform will be established to teach undergraduate minority students advanced applied sciences and provide research experiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this co-collaborative research project between a material scientist and two statisticians at the University of Wisconsin-Madison and Virginia Tech was to develop a statistics-guided framework for significantly enhancing the efficiency of nano-synthesis and the accuracy of nano-characterization. The framework is useful for scaling up the reproducibility, reliability and precision in nano-manufacturing. Through this three-year of the award, the team has made some significant contribution in building this framework. The framework consists of new and novel methods for experimental design, advanced modeling, and efficient fusion of data from multiple resources. It provides a new direction for the improvement of precision and the resolution of material characterization without enhancing instrumentation capabilities. It has also generated a set of systematic methods for scaling up nano-manufacturing process.

Major contributions of the project include, but are not limited to,  (1) a mixed variance component model with adaptive forward-backward group selection to accurately estimate the elastic modulus from the repeated deformation data; (2) a statistics-enabled predictive method for high-precision and high-resolution SPM characterizations of surface properties of nanomaterials; (3) a novel spatial calibration model to predict the hard-to-measure anisotropy of nano films using the easy-to-measure height of the nano films; (4) An ensemble modeling method for data fusion of both experimental and observational data in the manufacturing process, (5) A novel experimental design with economic run size for the manufacturing process involving both quantitative and qualitative factors and (6) A new design augmentation method, called level expansion, for sequential experiments.  This award has supported a number of papers in both top statistics and nano journals. The research results are also presented in various professional meetings and conferences, including Joint Statistical Meeting, INFORMS and ASA Spring Research Conference in industrial and engineering statistics.

Beyond nano-manufacturing, the developed methods have broad applications in other scientific areas. For example, the ensemble modeling method for data fusion of both experimental and observational data can be applied in the steel manufacturing process. The experimental design for both quantitative and qualitative factors and level expansion can be useful for the discovery of new polymeric membrane materials. The research of this project has led the development of new tools in design, modeling and analysis of complex experiments, which can be crucial to deal with the large data with complex structure.  Topics such as the new experimental designs are in the process of being incorporated into courses taught by the PIs.

Multiple education and outreach activities are organized for students to advance the understanding of nano-manufacturing equipped with the analytical skills. A workshop was organized for students from the underrepresented groups getting hands-on activities in advanced manufacturing and data mining. The workshop was part of C-Tech2 program as a pre-college initiative targeting on promoting rising junior and senior high school girls in engineering related majors and careers. Course modules on new experimental design and analysis methods have been integrated in the undergraduate and graduate courses. Those undergraduate students were trained on statistical modeling and experimental design in the carbon nanotube fabrication with the application of stronger steel manufacturing. The graduate students were trained with both experimental and analytical skills in the analysis of nano experimental data. In addition to the knowledge dissemination through publications and presentations for promoting this research area, research results from this project are also repo...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The purpose of this co-collaborative research project between a material scientist and two statisticians at the University of Wisconsin-Madison and Virginia Tech was to develop a statistics-guided framework for significantly enhancing the efficiency of nano-synthesis and the accuracy of nano-characterization. The framework is useful for scaling up the reproducibility, reliability and precision in nano-manufacturing. Through this three-year of the award, the team has made some significant contribution in building this framework. The framework consists of new and novel methods for experimental design, advanced modeling, and efficient fusion of data from multiple resources. It provides a new direction for the improvement of precision and the resolution of material characterization without enhancing instrumentation capabilities. It has also generated a set of systematic methods for scaling up nano-manufacturing process. Major contributions of the project include, but are not limited to, (1) a mixed variance component model with adaptive forward-backward group selection to accurately estimate the elastic modulus from the repeated deformation data; (2) a statistics-enabled predictive method for high-precision and high-resolution SPM characterizations of surface properties of nanomaterials; (3) a novel spatial calibration model to predict the hard-to-measure anisotropy of nano films using the easy-to-measure height of the nano films; (4) An ensemble modeling method for data fusion of both experimental and observational data in the manufacturing process, (5) A novel experimental design with economic run size for the manufacturing process involving both quantitative and qualitative factors and (6) A new design augmentation method, called level expansion, for sequential experiments. This award has supported a number of papers in both top statistics and nano journals. The research results are also presented in various professional meetings and conferences, including Joint Statistical Meeting, INFORMS and ASA Spring Research Conference in industrial and engineering statistics. Beyond nano-manufacturing, the developed methods have broad applications in other scientific areas. For example, the ensemble modeling method for data fusion of both experimental and observational data can be applied in the steel manufacturing process. The experimental design for both quantitative and qualitative factors and level expansion can be useful for the discovery of new polymeric membrane materials. The research of this project has led the development of new tools in design, modeling and analysis of complex experiments, which can be crucial to deal with the large data with complex structure. Topics such as the new experimental designs are in the process of being incorporated into courses taught by the PIs. Multiple education and outreach activities are organized for students to advance the understanding of nano-manufacturing equipped with the analytical skills. A workshop was organized for students from the underrepresented groups getting hands-on activities in advanced manufacturing and data mining. The workshop was part of C-Tech2 program as a pre-college initiative targeting on promoting rising junior and senior high school girls in engineering related majors and careers. Course modules on new experimental design and analysis methods have been integrated in the undergraduate and graduate courses. Those undergraduate students were trained on statistical modeling and experimental design in the carbon nanotube fabrication with the application of stronger steel manufacturing. The graduate students were trained with both experimental and analytical skills in the analysis of nano experimental data. In addition to the knowledge dissemination through publications and presentations for promoting this research area, research results from this project are also reported to NSF directors and industrial representatives during their visit to Virginia Tech.
